Being activated by methylalumoxane ([Al]/[Zr] = 10), (η5-C5H5)2ZrCl2 (Zr1) and [(η5-C5H4SiMe2)2O]ZrCl2 (Zr2) catalyze selective dimerization of α-olefins with low productivity (turnover number TON ∼2000). Our previous research of heterocycle-fused ansa-zirconocenes revealed that SiMe2-bridged complexes catalyze polymerization of α-olefins, whereas CH2CH2-bridged complexes are high-performance oligomerization catalysts (TON ∼ 4∙105). We proposed that further elongation of the bridge will allow obtaining dimerization catalysts. New –SiMe2OSiMe2– bridged ansa-zirconocenes Zr3–Zr11 were synthesized and studied in oct-1-ene dimerization at 100 °C and [oct-1-ene]/[Zr] ratio of 3∙104. In the absence of H2 bis(5,6-dihydroindeno[2,1-b]indole) derivatives Zr8 and Zr9 demonstrated high activity and dimerization selectivity up to 94%. In the presence of H2 symmetrical indenoindole complexes Zr5–Zr9 appeared to be even more active, but up to 24% of hydrogenated oct-1-ene dimer HC16 was formed. Mixed-ligand complexes Zr10 and Zr11 catalyzed oct-1-ene dimerization with up to 99% selectivity without the formation of HC16 even in trace amounts. Graphical Abstract Keywords Dimerization Methylenealkanes 5,6-dihydroindeno[2,1-b]indole α-olefins Zirconocenes Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Research and development of new fine chemicals encourages scientists to search for new types of feedstocks which may be used in the preparation of new materials with valuable properties. Among other petroleum-derived reactive hydrocarbons, methylenealkanes can be applied in the synthesis of different products containing long alkyl branched fragment ( Scheme 1) [1,2]. In the last decade, methylenealkanes have found application in the synthesis of lubricating oils [3–6], branched alcohols and their derivatives [7,8], branched carboxylic acids [9], dispersant additives [10–12], surfactants [13,14], phosphonate-based extragents [15,16], phosphonate friction modifiers [17], and others [1]. Organochemical approaches to methylenealkanes use successive treatment of ethyl chloroacetate or chloroacetyl chloride with Grignard reagents and lithium powder [18], the reaction of Me3SiCOOEt with Grignard reagents and acids [19] or Wittig reaction [20] (Scheme 1B). These approaches are complex, expensive and time-consuming, and low-cost catalytic alternative, selective dimerization of α-olefins, has been found successfully in 1980 s [21]. This reaction proceeds in the presence (η5-C5H5)2ZrCl2 (Zr1), activated by minimal amounts of methylalumoxane (МАО) (Scheme 1С). The prospects of the use of this reaction in the synthesis of methylenealkanes were studied by Christoffers and Bergman using linear α-olefins, allylbenzene and 1,2-diallylbenzene as a starting compounds [22,23]. In our studies of the ansa-zirconocenes of general formula [Z(η5-C5H4)2]ZrCl2 (Z – bridges of different lengths) we found that selectivity of hex-1-ene dimerization is directly related to the value of the dihedral angle between cyclopentadienyl rings, and the precatalyst Zr2 (Scheme 1C) with the longest –SiMe2OSiMe2– bridge and lowest dihedral angle demonstrates higher activity and selectivity in comparison with Zr1 and ansa-zirconocenes with shorter bridges [24]. During subsequent experimental and theoretical study of the catalytic behavior of Zr1 and Zr2 in oct-1-ene oligomerization we showed that coordination of the bridging oxygen atom at catalytic center can presumably increase the selectivity of dimerization [25]. A number of metallocene [26–31] and post-metallocene [32–35] pre-catalysts have been investigated in dimerization of α-olefins in later years,. However, in almost all cases highly selective dimerization of α-olefins required high catalyst loadings, ∼0.1 mol% and even more, that is not acceptable for practical use. Relatively low α-olefin/catalyst ratios also implies the presence of high excess of organoaluminum activators that may lead to the formation of Zr–Al alkyl transfer products and, after hydrolysis, non-removable admixtures of hydrogenated α-olefin dimers. Among other silngle-site catalysts, zirconocenes containing fused thiophene or pyrrole fragments, so-called heterocenes, are attractive due to their ability to catalyze Ziegler-Natta processes in the presence of minimal excess of MAO or R3Al/perfluoroaryl borate activators. In recent studies, we have demonstrated high catalytic efficiency of SiMe2-bridged ansa-heterocenes in oct-1-ene polymerization [36] and ethylene/oct-1-ene copolymerization for elastomer production [37]. Elongation of the bridge from –SiMe2– to –CH2CH2– with the same η5-ligands altered the catalytic behavior of heterocenes to oligomerization with a turnover number (TON) up to 4∙105 [38,39]. In the latter works, we showed that oligomerization of dec-1-ene at elevated temperatures results in excessive formation of dec-1-ene dimer. We proposed that the further elongation of the bridge in ansa-heterocenes from –CH2CH2– to –SiMe2OSiMe2– might lead to further increase of the selectivity of dimer formation. In the present article we describe the synthesis and X-ray diffraction study of new pre-catalysts, bis(fluorenyl) complex Zr3 and heterocenes Zr4–Zr11 ( Scheme 2), and present the results of comparative investigations of the catalytic behavior of Zr3–Zr11 in dimerization of oct-1-ene. With the use of Zr11, high-purity dimers of C8–C18 α-olefins were synthesized. 2 Experimental 2.1 Solvents and reagents All solvents and reagents were supplied by Merck (Darmstadt, Germany). n-Pentane, n-hexane and oct-1-ene were stored over Na and distilled under argon. Dec-1-ene, dodec-1-ene, tetradec-1-ene and octadec-1-ene were stored over Na and distilled in vacuo. Et2O, THF, benzene, toluene and N 1,N 1,N 2,N 2-tetramethylethane-1,2-diamine (TMEDA) were refluxed over Na/benzophenone and distilled under argon. Isopropylbenzene and tert-butylbenzene were distilled under reduced pressure. CH2Cl2 was refluxed over CaH2 and distilled. 2,3-Dihydro-1H-inden-1-one, 1H-inden-2(3H)-one, 9H-fluorene, 3-chloropropanoyl chloride, diethylene glycol, ethanol, isopropanol, phenylhydrazine, (2,4-dimethylphenyl)hydrazine, hydrazine hydrate, iodomethane, thiophene-2-carbaldehyde, ethyl dimethylcarbamate, 1,3-dichloro-1,1,3,3-tetramethyldisiloxane, H2SO4 (96%), p-TsOH, trimethylcetylammonium bromide, [1,3-bis(diphenylphosphino)propane]NiCl2, KOH, n-BuLi (2.5 M solution in hexanes), modified methylalumoxane (MMAO-12, 7 wt% solution in toluene), triisobutylaluminum (TIBA, 1 M solution in hexane), SiMe2Cl2, AlCl3 and ZrCl4 were used as purchased. Hydrogen (99.9999%, Linde Gas Russia, Balashikha, Russian Federation) was used without purification. 2,5-Dimethyl-7H-cyclopenta[1,2-b:4,3-b']dithiophene 1 [40,41], 5-methyl-5,10-dihydroindeno[1,2-b]indole 2 [42], 2-isopropyl-5-methyl-5,10-dihydroindeno[1,2-b]indole 3 [36], 2-tert-butyl-5-methyl-5,10-dihydroindeno[1,2-b]indole 4 [36], 5-methyl-5,6-dihydroindeno[2,1-b]indole 5 [43,44], zirconocene Zr2 [45] and [PhNHMe2][B(C6F5)4] (NBF) [46] were synthesized as previously described. 2.2 Analysis All deuterated solvents were supplied by Cambridge Isotope Laboratories, Inc. (Tewksbury, MA, USA). CDCl3 (D 99.8%) was used as purchased. CD2Cl2 (D 99.8%) was stored over CaH2 and condensed into NMR tubes. The 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AVANCE 400 spectrometer (400 MHz, Bruker Corporation, Billerica, MA, USA) at 20 °C. The chemical shifts are reported in ppm relative to the solvent residual peaks. Gas chromatography (GC) analysis was performed on a KRISTALL-2000 M gas chromatograph equipped with a SolGel-1 ms (60 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) column and a flame ionization detector. Helium was used as the carrier gas at the rate of 1.364 mL∙min–1 and with the split ratio of 73.3:1. The injection temperature was 320 °C, and the column temperature was 200 °C within 5 min before increasing from 200 °C to 300 °C at a rate of 10 °C∙min–1. Elemental analysis (C, H, N, O) was performed using a Perkin Elmer Series II CHNS/O Analyzer 2400 (Perkin Elmer, Waltham, MA, USA). 2.3 Synthesis of the ligand precursors L3–L12 and zirconocenes Zr3–Zr12 2.3.1 Synthesis of the ligand precursors L3–L9 The reactions were conducted in the argon atmosphere. Starting heterocycles 1–5 and 2,4,5-trimethyl-5,6-dihydroindeno[2,1-b]indole 6 (new compound, the synthesis of 6 is presented in Section S1.1 in the Appendix A) were dried at 0.01 Torr within 6 h. Calculated amount of fluorene or heterocyclic fluorene analog (1–6) was dissolved in THF at the rate of ∼2 mL∙mmol–1. After cooling to –70 °C, equimolar amount of n-BuLi (2.5 M in hexane) was added. The solution was allowed to warm to 20 °C, stirred for 8 h, and added to cooled (–70 °C) solution of 1,3-dichloro-1,1,3,3-tetramethyldisiloxane (0.5 equivalent in THF or Et2O, 3 mL∙mmol–1). The mixture was allowed to warm to 20 °C and stirred within 16 h. The precipitated product was filtered off, washed by appropriate solvent or recrystallized, and dried in vacuo. The yields of the bridged ligand precursors amounted to 65% (L3), 71% (L4), 30% (L5), 41% (L6), 42% (L7), 32% (L8), and 36% (L9). Experimental details and NMR spectra of L3–L9 are presented in Section S1.2 in the Appendix A. 2.3.2 Synthesis of the ligand precursors L10–L12 In the synthesis of non-symmetrical bridged ligand precursors, previously undescribed fluorene derivative 1-chloro-3-(9H-fluoren-9-yl)-1,1,3,3-tetramethyldisiloxane 7 was used (new compound, the synthesis of 7 is presented in Section S1.1 in the Appendix A). The reactions were conducted in the argon atmosphere. Calculated amount of heterocyclic fluorene analog (4, 5 or 6) was dissolved in THF at the rate of ∼4 mL∙mmol–1. After cooling to –70 °C, equimolar amount of n-BuLi (2.5 M in hexane) was added. The solution was allowed to warm to 20 °C, stirred for 12 h, and added to cooled (–70 °C) solution of 7 (1 equivalent in THF, ∼4 mL∙mmol–1). The mixture was allowed to warm to 20 °C and stirred within 16 h. The precipitated product was filtered off, washed by appropriate solvent or recrystallized, and dried in vacuo. The yields of the bridged ligand precursors amounted to 48% (L10), 39% (L11), and 15% (L12). Experimental details and NMR spectra of L10–L12 are presented in Section S1.2 in the Appendix A. 2.3.3 Synthesis of the zirconocenes Zr3–Zr11 The synthesis, separation and purification of Zr3–Zr11 were conducted in the argon atmosphere using Schlenk lines and glovebox. Calculated volume of n-BuLi (2.5 M in hexane, 2.05 equivalents) was added to cooled (–70 °C) suspension of ligand precursor in the mixture of Et2O (∼15 mL∙mmol–1) and THF (0.8 mL∙mmol–1). The mixture was allowed to warm to 20 °C, stirred for 12 h, the solvents were eliminated in vacuo. Toluene (∼20 mL∙mmol–1) was added, the mixture was cooled to –40 °С, and calculated amount of ZrCl4 (1 equivalent) was added. The mixture was allowed to warm to 20 °C, and stirred for 12 h. After elimination of the solvents, CH2Cl2 (∼15 mL∙mmol–1) was added, the solution of the complex was filtered and evaporated. The residue was recrystallized from 1:1 CH2Cl2/hexane mixture. Experimental details, descriptions of the separation of diastereomeric forms and NMR spectra of Zr3–Zr11 are presented in Section S1.3 in the Appendix A. 2.4 X-ray diffraction study Single crystals of zirconium complexes were obtained by slow evaporation of the saturated solutions of zirconocenes in CH2Cl2/hexane mixtures using the following CH2Cl2/hexane ratios: 1:1 (Zr3, Zr4), 1:2 (Zr10, Zr11), 1:3 (Zr6r, Zr7r) and 1:5 (Zr9m). Single crystals of Zr7m were obtained using 1:3 toluene/hexane mixture as a solvent. X-ray diffraction data were collected at 100 K on a four-circle Rigaku Synergy S diffractometer (Rigaku Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) equipped with a HyPix6000HE area-detector (kappa geometry, shutterless ω-scan technique) using monochromatized Cu Kα-radiation (Zr3, Zr7r, Zr7m∙1.5 toluene, Zr9m, Zr10, Zr11∙0.5 H2O) or Mo Kα-radiation (Zr4∙2 CH2Cl2, Zr6r∙CH2Cl2). The crystal data and the details of structure refinement are presented in Section S2 in the Appendix A. The structures of Zr3, Zr4, Zr6r, Zr7r, Zr7m, Zr9m, Zr10 and Zr11 have been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC) with the reference CCDC numbers 2333154–2333161, they also contain the supplementary crystallographic data. This information may be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. 2.5 Catalytic experiments 2.5.1 Comparative oct-1-ene dimerization experiments Dimerization experiments were conducted using standard round-bottom two-necked flasks connected with Schlenk line and equipped with heating bath. Oct-1-ene (28.6 g, 0.255 mol) was placed into flask filled with argon, TIBA (1 M solution in n-hexane, 0.255 mL, 0.255 mmol) and Zr precatalyst (8.5 μmol) were added. To carry out the dimerization in the presence of molecular hydrogen, at this stage the flask was degassed and filled with H2 (during the reaction the pressure is kept constant, 1 Bar). The external bath (ethylene glycol) was heated to 100 °C, and after 20 min MMAO-12 (1.2 M solution in toluene, 0.085 mmol) or NBF (7.5 mg, 0.0094 mmol, 1.1 eq.) was added. The mixture was stirred for 2–4 h, cooled to 20 °C, treated by 10% solution of Na2CO3 (1 mL) and Na2SO4 (2 g), and passed through 2 cm layer of neutral alumina. The product was analyzed by NMR spectroscopy and GC. Experimental details, the methods of the calculations of the product compositions and NMR spectra of the reaction products are presented in Section S3 in the Appendix A. 2.5.2 Analysis of the reaction products Analysis of the composition of the products of oct-1-ene dimerization (oligomerization) was conducted with the use of 1H NMR and GC data. Because of the characteristics of the selected operation mode, GC analysis was not used for the determination of C8 components (starting oct-1-ene, oct-2-enes, n-octane). Analysis was performed using n-dodecane as an internal standard; preliminary calibration was made using the mixture containing weighted amounts of oct-1-ene, oct-1-ene trimer, tetramer and pentamer, correction factors for integral intensities of C16, C24, C36 and C40 were determined and accounted for 1.05, 1.13, 1.29 and 1.49, respectively. C40+ fractions, constituting a mixtures of diastereomers (8 for C48, etc) are not detectable with reasonable accuracy by GC, and the content of higher oct-1-ene oligomers was estimated by the weighting of the residue after distilling off at 250 °C/0.1 Torr the reaction products up to oct-1-ene pentamer (B. p. 242 °C/0.2 Torr [47]). This measurement was not carried out if the content of C40 fraction was 2 wt% or less. 1H NMR analysis of the reaction mixtures was found to be highly efficient for catalytic systems with high dimerization selectivity. Based on integral intensities of the characteristic signals of vinyl protons of oct-1-ene, oct-2-enes, =CH2 fragments of dimer and oligomers, as well as the signals of the terminal –CH3 groups (common triplet at 0.89 ppm for oct-1-ene, oct-2-enes, n-octane, dimer and higher oct-1-ene oligomers) and methyl group of the >CH–CH3 fragment in hydrogenated oct-1-ene dimer (doublet at 0.85 ppm), the relative ratios of the reaction products were determined (for details see Section S3.2 in the Appendix A). 2.5.3 Synthesis of α-olefin dimers Freshly distilled α-olefin (0.25 mol) was placed into the flask filled with H2, TIBA (1 M solution in n-hexane, 0.25 mL, 0.25 mmol) and precatalyst Zr11 (5.63 mg, 8.33 μmol) were added. The external bath was heated to 100 °C, and after 20 min NBF (7.3 mg, 9.16 μmol, 1.1 eq.) was added, and the reaction mixture was stirred for 4 h. After treatment described in Section 2.5.1, the layer of alumina was washed by hexane, the solution was evaporated under reduced pressure and distilled in vacuo collecting a wide fractions boiling at 100–120 °C/0.8 Torr (oct-1-ene dimer), 120–140 °C/0.5 Torr (dec-1-ene dimer), 140–160 °C/0.2 Torr (dodec-1-ene dimer), 180–200 °C/0.2 Torr (tetradec-1-ene dimer) and 190–220 °C/0.1 Torr (octadec-1-ene dimer). In all cases there was no residue after distillation. NMR spectra of α-olefin dimers are presented in Section S3 in the Appendix A. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Synthesis and molecular structure of the complexes Zr3–Zr12 Only a few examples of the ansa-zirconocenes with –SiMe2OSiMe2– bridge are known from the scientific periodicals and patent literature. Bis(η5-cyclopentadienyl) dichloro complex Zr2 was synthesized previously by the hydrolysis of (η5-C5H4SiMe2Cl)ZrCl2 [48]. Zr2 and [(3- t Bu-η5-C5H3SiMe2)2O]ZrCl2 were prepared starting from the corresponding bridged ligand precursors [45]. The second method was also used in the synthesis of bis(η5-inden-1-yl) [49–53] and bis(η5-inden-2-yl) [54] complexes. The complex Zr3, as well as a number of mixed-ligand SiOSi-bridged zirconium complexes, have been claimed but not characterized in the patent literature [53,55]. In our studies, we selected the common approach to the complexes Zr3–Zr11 that includes the synthesis of the ansa-ligand precursors. 3.1.1 Synthesis of the ligand precursors L3–L12 In the synthesis of L3–L9 we used modified method of the preparation of 1,3-di(1H-inden-1-yl)-1,1,3,3-tetramethyldisiloxane [49]. Bis(9H-fluoren-9-yl) ligand precursor L3 was synthesized previously in two stages, by the reaction of fluorenyllithium (FluLi) with an excess of SiMe2Cl2, followed by the hydrolysis of FluSiMe2Cl; the total yield was 64% [56]. In our experiments, the reaction of FluLi with (ClSiMe2)2O resulted in obtaining of L3 with 65% yield ( Scheme 3). Heterocyclic symmetrical ligand precursors L4–L9 were prepared by the same way starting from 2,5-dimethyl-7H-cyclopenta[1,2-b:4,3-b']dithiophene 1 [40,41], substituted 5,10-dihydroindeno[1,2-b]indoles 2–4 [36,42], 5-methyl-5,6-dihydroindeno[2,1-b]indole 5 [43,44] and undescribed 2,4,5-trimethyl-5,6-dihydroindeno[2,1-b]indole 6 (see Section S1.1 in the Appendix A). The yields amounted to 36–48%, L4 represented individual compound, whereas L5–L9 were formed as a mixtures of diastereomers; for L7, L8 and L9 less soluble diastereomers were separated (see Section S1.2 in the Appendix A). To prepare non-symmetrical ansa-ligand precursors L10–L12, we first synthesized 1-chloro-3-(9H-fluoren-9-yl)-1,1,3,3-tetramethyldisiloxane FluSiMe2OSiMe2Cl 7, separated by distillation in vacuo with 41% yield. Further, 7 was reacted with lithium derivatives of 4–6 (Scheme 3), the yields of L10, L11 and L12 amounted to 48, 39 and 15%, respectively. 3.1.2 Synthesis of the complexes Zr3–Zr11 The synthesis of ansa-zirconocenes is complicated by the formation of oligomeric and polymeric products, the presence of long –SiMe2OSiMe2– bridge only makes it harder to achieve high yields of the ansa-complexes. To provide conditions of Ziegler-Ruggli high dilution principle, the dilithium derivatives of the ligands L3–L12 were separated as solids, and their subsequent reaction with ZrCl4 was carried out in toluene in the presence of minimal amount of THF. The yields of C2v-symmetrical ansa-complexes Zr3 and Zr4 were 38% and 36%, respectively. The synthesis of heterocenes, based on symmetrical ligand precursors L5–L9, was complicated by the formation of the mixtures of C2-symmetrical rac- and Cs-symmetrical meso-forms of the complexes. The reaction of L5 with n-BuLi, followed by the addition of ZrCl4, resulted in formation of the mixture of Zr5 diastereomers with a rac-/meso- ratio of ∼1:1, after three repeated recrystallizations rac-/meso- ratio of ∼3:1 was achieved. The complex Zr6 was also formed as a 1:1 rac-/meso- mixture, pure rac-diastereomer Zr6r was separated with 11% yield, the yield of Zr6m (85% diastereomeric purity) was 1%. Diastereomers of Zr7 were separated with the use of fractional crystallization, the yields of Zr7r and Zr7m were 17 and 9%, respectively. In the case of Zr8 we observed preferential formation of the rac-form, however, the closeness of the solubilities of diastereomeric forms was the cause of only 8% isolated yield of Zr8r. In the case of Zr9, we also observed close solubility of diastereomers, the yields were 17% for rac-enriched (63%) Zr9r and 4% for pure Zr9m. The assignment of the obtained diastereomers of Zr5–Zr9 to rac- or meso-type using 1H NMR spectroscopy turned out to be no trivial matter. In contrast to –SiMe2– bridged complexes, the signals of bridging methyl groups are doubled for both diastereomers (see Figs. S9–S42 the Appendix A). However, based on the results of X-ray diffraction analysis (see Section 3.1.3), it can be concluded that the difference between chemical shifts of Si–Me groups for rac-forms is higher in comparison with the distance between Si–Me signals for meso-forms. The similar spectral pattern was observed previously for bis(η5-inden-1-yl) SiOSi-bridged complex [49]. The problem of separation and identification of diastereomers can be avoided when using non-symmetrical ligand precursors L10–L12, thereby C1-symmetrical ansa-complexes Zr10 and Zr11 were obtained with 41 and 46% yields, respectively. However, repeated attempts to synthesize zirconium complex Zr12 failed. 3.1.3 X-ray diffraction studies The molecular structures of Zr3, Zr4, Zr6r, Zr7r, Zr7m, Zr9m, Zr10 and Zr11 are presented in Fig. 1. The details of the X-ray diffraction (XRD) experiments are given in Section S2.1 in the Appendix A. The coordination environment of the Zr atom in all complexes can be characterized as a distorted tetrahedron (assuming that the η5-C5 rings occupy a single coordination site). The Zr–C distances vary in a wide range of 2.40–2.80 Å, the average distance Zr–Cen (Cen – centroid of the cyclopentadienyl ring) is lowest for bis(fluorenyl) complex Zr3, and the average Zr–Cl distance is minimal for the same complex. This difference can be attributed to electron donor properties of fused heterocycles in η5-ligands. We were not able to identify any patterns in the change of the values of Cen–Zr–Cen' angle depending on the structure of the complexes. At the same time, the marked difference in the values of dihedral angles was observed, these values were minimal for 5,6-dihydroindeno[2,1-b]indole derivative Zr9m and mixed-ligand complexes Zr10 and Zr11 Table 1. 3.2 Dimerization of oct-1-ene 3.2.1 Results of the dimerization experiments in the absence of H2 Dimerization experiments were carried out using a two-stage activation method [36,47], by the reactions of dichloro complexes Zr1–Zr11 with TIBA (30 eq.) in oct-1-ene reaction media ([Oct-1-ene]/[Zr] = 3∙104) at 100 °C, followed by the treatment with MMAO-12 (10 eq.) or NBF (1.1 eq.) and stirring at this temperature. After a given period of time, the reaction mixtures were analyzed by GC and 1H NMR spectroscopy. In some cases, gravimetric measurement of the weights of non-volatile oligomerization products was used (see Section 2.6). At high [oct-1-ene]/[Zr] ratios and at elevated temperature (100 °C) the benchmark complex Zr1 showed moderate catalytic activity and low selectivity in oct-1-ene dimerization. For simple and fast estimation of the selectivity of dimerization, we used selectivity factor (SF in the Table 2) representing the mol.% of vinylidene dimer in the mixture of vinylidene oligomers and determined SF as a ratio of the integral intensities of the =CH2 fragments of dimer (singlet at 4.69 ppm) and other oligomers (singlets at 4.74 and 4.68 ppm) in 1H NMR spectra. In the case of Zr1, SF was 75 and 59 mol.% when using activation by MMAO-12 and NBF, respectively (Table 2, Entries 1 and 2). Activation of the complex Zr2 by low amounts of MMAO-12 failed. When using NBF activator, high conversion was achieved (Table 2, Entry 4), but non-selective oligomerization was observed. In out previous study [25], Zr2 showed similar low selectivity in oct-1-ene oligomerization at 60 °C being activated by NBF. It is appropriate to mention here that in our previous studies [24,25] of Zr1 and Zr2 both zirconocenes were efficient in oct-1-ene dimerization at [oct-1-ene]/[Zr] ratio of 2∙103 at 60 °C. During theses studies, high dimerization selectivities were achieved, and the use of the molecular hydrogen only promoted the formation of dimers. However, these precatalysts have been ineffective at elevated temperatures. The failure of the use of Zr1 and Zr2 in catalytic experiments at 100 °C can be expllained by the low stability of the catalytic species that results in formation of the species that catalyze non-selective oligomerization. Bis(fluorenyl) complex Zr3 and heterocene Zr4 showed low activity in the presence of MMAO-12 and NBF (Table 2, Entries 5–8). The derivative of 5-methyl-5,6-dihydroindeno[1,2-b]indole Zr5 turned out to be completely inactive, however, the introduction of isopropyl (Zr6r) or tert-butyl (Zr7) substituents to the position 2 of indeno[1,2-b]indole has led to the emergence of moderate activity, and as it turned out the NBF was the better activator. In the case of Zr7 the geometry of the complex (rac- or meso-) substantially affected the selectivity of the dimerization, the maximum SF (91.4 mol.%) was observed when Zr7r was activated by NBF (Table 2, Entry 14). Note that in the case of Zr7 the selectivity of dimerization did not correlate with the value of dihedral angle between cyclopentadienyl planes (Cp–Cp'), the meso-form Zr7m (Cp–Cp' = 51.94°) was less selective (Table 2, Entries 15 and 16) in comparison with the rac-form Zr7r (Cp–Cp' = 55.87°). Unexpected and promising result was obtained when studying 5,6-dihydroindeno[2,1-b]indole derivatives Zr8 and Zr9 (Table 2, Entries 17–25). Activation by MMAO-12 was not effective for both complexes, whereas NBF has proved capable of the formation of active species: in the case of Zr8r after 2 h 87% conversion vas observed (98% after 4 h), and selectivity factor (SF) was 95.5 mol.% (Table 2, Entry 19). Crude meso-form Zr8m demonstrated similar catalytic behavior – in this way, in the case of Zr8 there is no special need to separate diastereomers. Unlike Zr8, activated by MMAO-12 racemo-enriched heterocene Zr9r showed low activity and selectivity, activation of meso-form Zr9m by MMAO-12 failed. When using NBF as an activator, both forms demonstrated high activity and selectivity (Table 2, Entries 23 and 25). Zr9m showed notably higher activity and SF (94.0 mol.%), and lower oct-2-ene content. More synthetically available mixed-ligand complexes Zr10 and Zr11 were poorly activated by MMAO-12. In the presence of NBF Zr10 showed moderate activity (32% conversion after 4 h) but high selectivity (SF = 96.8 mol.%). 3.2.2 Results of the dimerization experiments in the presence of H2 The main problem of oligomerization in the presence of H2 is caused by simultaneous hydrogenation with a formation of n-octane, 7-methylpentadecane (hydrogenated dimer of oct-1-ene, HC16) and higher hydrogenated oligomers. GC analysis of the reaction mixtures becomes even more complicated, and reliable analysis of these mixtures is possible for selective dimerization cases with the use of 1H NMR spectral data. The formation of HC16 is easily detected on 1H NMR spectra by the presence of characteristic doublet at 0.85 ppm (see Fig. 2). For the complexes Zr1–Zr11 the presence of H2 usually led to increased activity ( Table 3). The benchmark complex Zr1 showed moderate activities being activated by MMAO-12 and NBF; notably, both n-octane and HC16 do not form when using Zr1, but low selectivity makes this catalyst of little use for dimerization (Table 3, Entries 1, 2). Precatalyst Zr2 turned out to be more active (Table 3, Entries VF-83, VF-90) but had lower selectivity. And more importantly, Zr2 catalyzed the formation of both n-octane and HC16, totally more than 20 wt%. In the presence of the molecular hydrogen, new zirconocenes Zr3–Zr11 have shown qualitatively different catalytic behavior. Bis(fluorenyl) complex Zr3, activated by TIBA and MMAO-12, demonstrated moderate activity and relatively high selectivity (SF = 93.8, Table 3, Entry 5). When using NBF as an activator, we observed a two-fold increase in the productivity and excellent selectivity of the formation of dimer (SF = 99.6, Table 3, Entry 6, see also Fig. 3 A). According to literature data, such a high level of the selectivity of dimerization has never been achieved previously in coordination oligomerization of α-olefins. One would think that the desired catalyst is found, however, Zr3-based system cannot be employed in practice since more than a third of the starting oct-1-ene transforms to n-octane, i.e. Zr3 represents efficient catalyst of the hydrogenation of α-olefins. At the same time, hydrogenated dimer of oct-1-ene was not formed when using Zr3/TIBA/NBF system (Fig. 3 A), which is extremely unusual for single-site oligomerization catalysts. Low activity of Zr4 in dimerization (Table 3, Entries 7 and 8) was another quite unexpected and interesting result, given that SiMe2-bridged cyclopenta[1,2-b:4,3-b']dithiophene-based Zr complexes were not inferior to other heterocenes on catalytic activity in oct-1-ene polymerization [36]. Being activated by TIBA and MMAO-12, Zr4 catalyzed hydrogenation of oct-1-ene, in the presence of TIBA and NBF the catalyst was inactive. Zirconocene Zr5 catalyzed selective dimerization of oct-1-ene (SF > 98 mol.%), activation by TIBA/NBF was more efficient and the reaction was almost completed after 2 h (Table 3, Entry 10). However, both n-octane and HC16 were formed thereby discounting the catalytic potential of this complex. The formation of HC16 was even higher when using isopropyl- and tert-butyl substituted indeno[1,2-b]indole complexes Zr6 and Zr7 (Table 3, Entries 11–16), the meso-form Zr7m has shown low dimerization selectivity (SI ∼65 mol.%). Symmetrical ansa-complexes based on substituted indeno[2,1-b]indoles Zr8 and Zr9 (Table 3, Entries 17–24) showed high activities but not the highest dimerization selectivities, with a large losses of the starting monomer on n-octane and HC16 formation. In retrospect of our study, based on the results of Zr3–Zr9 oligomerization tests it is at this point we decided to prepare the non-symmetrical complexes Zr10 and Zr11. This decision was taken with regard to the assumption that mixed-ligand catalysts could combine the advantages of both types of η5-ligands, fluorenyl (no HC16 formation) and indenoindole (higher activity). As mentioned above, additional preference of mixed-ligand complexes containing fluorenyl fragment is their C1 symmetry, which greatly simplifies the synthesis of the pre-catalysts owing to the absence of the stage of diastereomer separation. Overall, our expectations have been met, despite the failure with the synthesis of Zr12. In oct-1-ene dimerization experiments, the complex Zr10, activated by TIBA and MMAO-12, showed higher activity and selectivity in comparison with TIBA/NBF activation (Table 3, Entries 25 and 26), the reactions proceeded with a formation of substantial amounts of n-octane, HC16 was not detected. Activation of indeno[2,1-b]indole derivative Zr11 by MMAO-12 yielded moderately active catalyst of dimerization (Table 3, Entry 27), HC16 was not detected in this experiment. Notably, when 100 equivalents of MMAO-12 were used for activation of Zr11, the reaction was almost completed after 2 h (Table 3, Entry 28), but SI decreased to 98 mol.% and dimer fraction contained ∼17% of HC16. When TIBA/NBF was used for activation of Zr11, oct-2-enes and n-octane were by-products, higher oligomers were detected in trace amounts by GC and were invisible in the field of vinyl protons of the 1H NMR spectra (see Fig. 3 and Fig. S55 in the Appendix A). We assumed that the complex Zr11 can be used for the synthesis of α-olefin dimers of high purity and conducted preparative experiments with a number of linear α-olefins under the hydrogen atmosphere using activation of Zr11 by TIBA/NBF. As can be seen in Table 4 below, as the length of α-olefin chain increased, the α-olefin conversion and the yield of α-olefin dimer decreased, as a natural consequence of decrease in the concentration of –CH=CH2. The percentage of n-alkane in the reaction products also increased on passing from C8 to C18 α-olefin. The isolated yields of α-olefin dimers after vacuum distillation correlated with the results of analyses of the reaction mixtures. It is noteworthy that in all cases distilled α-olefin dimers did not contain hydrogenated dimers (see Figs. S56–S65 in the Appendix A). Note that during previous studies of zirconocene-catalyzed α-olefin oligomerization in inert atmosphere [47] methylenealkanes with lower level of purity were obtained due to the Zr–Al transfer. 3.2.3 Discussion of the dimerization experiments Conventional mechanism of zirconocene-catalyzed dimerization of α-olefins is presented in Scheme 4. Under reaction conditions, the initial stage with a high probability includes the formation of L2Zr–iBu cationic species (a) that are capable of coordination and insertion of oct-1-ene molecule. Subsequent β-hydride elimination or β-hydride transfer can lead to the formation of methylenealkane with isobutyl fragment and zirconocene species (b) or (c). Two weak signals at 4.77 and 4.82 ppm in 1H NMR spectra of the reaction mixtures, obtained in the presence of low-active Zr1, can be attributed to Me2CHCH2C(=CH2)(CH2)5Me. Highly active cationic species (b) can react with oct-1-ene with a formation of the product of 1,2-insertion (c) or more inert product of 2,1-insertion (d), the latter is the source of oct-2-enes and n-octane (in the presence of H2). Zr–n-octyl species (c) can also undergo hydrogenolysis. In the absence of H2, the main further transformation of (c) is a coordination/insertion of the second oct-1-ene molecule with a formation of (e), the source of the oct-1-ene dimer and, in the presence of H2, hydrogenated dimer HC16. As shown earlier [36,57,58], β-hexyl elimination and chain-walking via intermediate allyl formation are quite possible during coordination oligomerization of α-olefins. 1H NMR markers for these processes are characteristic signals of allyl and C(Me)=C(H)C6H13 end groups, respectively. It is impossible to completely exclude the presence of allyl end-groups due to the proximity of their signals in 1H NMR spectra to the signals of the starting oct-1-ene. However, in all our experiments the characteristic and non-overlapping signals of C(Me)=C(H)C6H13 were not detected, so there is a high likelihood that allyl intermediates can be excluded. In this way, the Scheme 4 reflects the processes during oct-1-ene oligomerization quite adequately. The experiments on oct-1-ene dimerization showed that the presence of the H2 resulted in an increase of the activity in most cases. Conventional view of the influence of H2 on the catalytic behavior of zirconocene catalysts is the reactivation of the Zr(IV) sites containing secondary alkyl fragments (regio-errors) and allyl species [59], and this mechanism of the re-activation was confirmed by the results of the experiments (high n-octane content in many cases). However, we have not detected the formation of allyl species, the characteristic signals of the chain termination via the formation of allyl intermediates were not observed. In this way, the activating impact of the molecular hydrogen is not well understood. It can not be excluded that H2 can re-activate inactive Zr (III) species that can be formed by the reaction of Zr(IV)–Al hydride intermediates with iBu2AlH [60]. However, in our previous study [61], we observed activating effect of the H2 for Zr1/TIBA/MMAO-12 catalytic system, and attributed this experimental fact to reactivation of agostic Zr–H–Al dormant species. It can be assumed that the role of the molecular hydrogen in catalytic behavior of zirconocenes under study is a coordination at Zr center with the destruction of the agostic intermediates formed at the initial stage of the α-olefin insertion, and thereby facilitating the insertion of the second α-olefin molecule. In the case of Zr1-based catalysts (Table 3, Entries 1 and 2) both hydrogenation products, n-octane and HC16, were virtually absent in the reaction mixtures, which is consistent with the results of [61]. Apparently, for other zirconocenes under study, the weakening of the agostic interactions via Zr – H2 coordination can also be a cause of activation by molecular hydrogen. However, the possibility of Zr…O coordination can not be ignored for SiOSi-bridged Zr2–Zr11, in our previous work we estimated the energy of similar coordination by the value of 9 kcal∙mol–1 [25]. In this way, in the case of SiOSi bridged complexes, oct-1-ene oligomerization is a very complex process, in the course of which coordination/insertion of oct-1-ene and H2, as well as coordination/decoordination of SiOSi fragment and organoaluminum species are possible and compete with each other. In particular for Zr11-based catalyst, the formation of Zr-Al catalytic species can be assumed basing on the results of catalytic experiment with the use of 100 equivalents of MMAO-12. An excess of MMAO-12, that acts as "organoaluminum sponge", promotes the formation of less hindered and more active catalytic species as reflected in manyfold increase of oligomerization activity, decrease of dimerization selectivity and formation of hydrogenated oct-1-ene dimer. The search of the dimerization catalyst by in silico methods for such a complex system is of little prospect. In the present study, we have synthesized a broad set of the pre-catalysts to discover trends in the experimental data. Perhaps the most interesting among experimental results is a unique behavior of fluorenyl complexes Zr3, Zr10 and Zr11. The absence of HC16 in the reaction products along with ∼100% selectivity of the dimer formation in the case of Zr3, Zr10 and Zr11 suggest that Zr–n-octyl intermediate is capable for coordination/insertion of both H2 and oct-1-ene molecules, while the reaction with hydrogen proceeds faster (in view of the very small concentration of H2 in the reaction media). However, the continued coordination/insertion of the second oct-1-ene molecule is followed by immediate chain release via β-hydride elimination (not β-hydride transfer), which indirectly indicates the participance of organoaluminum species in the formation of type (e) intermediate in Scheme 4. 4 Conclusions In summary, based on fluorene and synthetically available heterocyclic analogs of fluorene – substituted cyclopenta[1,2-b:4,3-b']dithiophene, 5,10-dihydroindeno[1,2-b]indoles and 5,6-dihydroindeno[2,1-b]indoles – we synthesized a series of new –SiMe2OSiMe2– bridged ansa-zirconocenes Zr3–Zr11, and confirmed molecular structures of these complexes by NMR spectroscopy and X-ray diffraction analysis. These complexes, activated by TIBA (30 eq.) and then by MMAO-12 (10 eq.) or by NBF (1.1 eq.), were studied in oct-1-ene dimerization at [oct-1-ene]/[Zr] molar ratio of 3∙104 in the absence and in the presence of the molecular hydrogen. In the absence of the molecular hydrogen, MMAO-12 activated bis(5,6-dihydroindeno[2,1-b]indole) derivatives Zr8 and Zr9 were almost inactive, however, these complexes have demonstrated high activity and dimerization selectivity up to 94% when NBF was used as an activator. In the atmosphere of the molecular hydrogen, NBF-activated bis(fluorenyl) complex Zr3 showed moderate activity and extremely high selectivity of the dimer formation (>99.6 mol.%), but more than a third of the starting oct-1-ene had been hydrogenated; it is noteworthy that the reaction products contained no hydrogenated oct-1-ene dimer. In contrast to Zr3, bis(5,10-dihydroindeno[1,2-b]indole) derivatives Zr5–Zr7 and bis(5,6-dihydroindeno[2,1-b]indole) derivatives Zr8 and Zr9 catalyzed the formation of hydrogenated oct-1-ene dimer to a greater extent. Mixed-ligand complexes, containing one fluorenyl fragment, were inferior to symmetrical heterocenes in activity, a substantial part of the starting oct-1-ene (8.1–15.1%) was hydrogenated. But, nevertheless, when using Zr10 and Zr11 hydrogenated dimers were not formed, and for Zr11/TIBA/NBF catalytic system more than 99% selectivity of the oct-1-ene dimerization was achieved. With the use of Zr11/TIBA/NBF catalyst, high purity dimers of oct-1-ene, dec-1-ene, dodec-1-ene, tetradec-1-ene and octadec-1-ene were synthesized. The results of the present work let us map out the areas of the further development of the prospective α-olefin dimerization catalysts through the design of the corresponding bridged bis(η5-ligands), and the long –SiOSi– bridge appears to be a promising structural fragment. coredata.dc:description: Being activated by methylalumoxane ([Al]/[Zr] = 10), (η5-C5H5)2ZrCl2 (Zr1) and [(η5-C5H4SiMe2)2O]ZrCl2 (Zr2) catalyze selective dimerization of α-olefins with low productivity (turnover number TON ∼2000). Our previous research of heterocycle-fused ansa-zirconocenes revealed that SiMe2-bridged complexes catalyze polymerization of α-olefins, whereas CH2CH2-bridged complexes are high-performance oligomerization catalysts (TON ∼ 4∙105). We proposed that further elongation of the bridge will allow obtaining dimerization catalysts. New –SiMe2OSiMe2– bridged ansa-zirconocenes Zr3–Zr11 were synthesized and studied in oct-1-ene dimerization at 100 °C and [oct-1-ene]/[Zr] ratio of 3∙104. In the absence of H2 bis(5,6-dihydroindeno[2,1-b]indole) derivatives Zr8 and Zr9 demonstrated high activity and dimerization selectivity up to 94%. In the presence of H2 symmetrical indenoindole complexes Zr5–Zr9 appeared to be even more active, but up to 24% of hydrogenated oct-1-ene dimer HC16 was formed. Mixed-ligand complexes Zr10 and Zr11 catalyzed oct-1-ene dimerization with up to 99% selectivity without the formation of HC16 even in trace amounts.
coredata.dc:title: Rational design of ansa-heterocenes with a long SiOSi bridge as a catalysts for selective dimerization of oct-1-ene
